lens.analysis_angle: Marketplace's RPV framework is built for general commerce, not housing trust. Performance oversupply on browsing, catastrophic undersupply on trust. 9/10 disappointments validated by transcripts.

elements.name: Verified Identity Trust Stack
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests commit thousands of dollars based on a profile photo. Hosts like Patricia have been scammed twice. Tag's default assumption is fraud. No platform provides housing-specific trust signals -- the entire category relies on social media profiles as the sole proxy for trustworthiness.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in any marketplace category provides a stacked, multi-source trust credential system designed for shared housing cohabitation. Moving from 'a profile photo and a prayer' to a layered verification display with progressive disclosure creates the single largest emotional shift in the housing search experience. The surprise factor is maximum because users have been conditioned to accept zero trust infrastructure.
elements.description: A vertical trust credential stack displayed on the listing detail page beside the host avatar. Each credential is a discrete, verifiable layer: Identity Verified (government ID), Background Checked, Income Verified, Housing Reviews (count + average across dimensions), Response Rate, and Listing Freshness ('Verified available 2h ago'). Credentials use progressive disclosure -- collapsed to icons with labels by default, expandable to show verification details. The stack uses a visual 'fill' metaphor: more credentials = more of the vertical bar filled with purple, creating an instant System 1 trust read. Unverified fields show as empty outlines, not hidden, so users understand what COULD be verified.

elements.name: Schedule-First Search with Day-of-Week Selector
elements.problem_it_solves: No platform in any category can express schedule-based housing needs. Tom needs Mon-Thu. Walaa needs weekdays + every other weekend. Vince needs flexibility to drop from 2 nights to 1. Every marketplace search uses location/price/bedrooms -- the concept of 'which nights do you need?' does not exist. Users must individually message hosts to explain non-standard scheduling, facing confusion and rejection.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: This IS Split Lease's reason for existence. Schedule-based housing search is the disruptive beachhead per Ch 9 -- the attribute that traditional platforms dismiss as too niche but which, once properly served, redefines the category. No competitor can copy this without rebuilding their core data model from scratch. The moment a hybrid worker selects 'Tue, Wed, Thu' and sees matching listings with per-night pricing is the moment Split Lease proves it was built for them.
elements.description: A hero search component where the primary interaction is selecting days of the week, not entering a location. Seven circular day badges (M T W T F S S) sit at the center of the search experience. The user taps the nights they need. Below, a duration selector (4 weeks, 8 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, custom) and a location field. As days are selected, a live cost estimate appears: '$87/night x 3 nights x 4 weeks = $1,044/mo.' The search button says 'Find Matches' and returns listings ranked by schedule compatibility. The entire component communicates: schedule is the organizing principle, not an afterthought.

elements.problem_it_solves: Listing cards on every platform show property photos, price, and location. None show schedule compatibility or person-level information. A hybrid worker scanning results has no way to see which listings match their weekly pattern without clicking into each one. The listing card tells you about a room, not about a living arrangement.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: A listing card that leads with schedule-fit percentage and day-of-week badges before showing price or photos inverts the entire information hierarchy of every marketplace in the category. It communicates instantly that this platform understands schedule-based housing as the primary decision axis.
elements.description: A listing card designed for search results where schedule compatibility is the first visual signal. The top section shows 7 small day-of-week dots with matched days highlighted in purple and a percentage badge ('92% match'). Below: host name + avatar (not just property), a single hero photo, nightly rate with monthly projection based on the guest's selected schedule, and 2-3 housing-specific tags (e.g., 'Quiet after 10pm', 'Dedicated workspace', 'Weekly cleaning'). The card communicates: 'Here is a person whose schedule and living style fit yours' -- not just 'here is a room.'

elements.name: Structured Proposal Builder with Smart Defaults
elements.problem_it_solves: Housing negotiation happens through 47-message Messenger threads spread over days. Terms get lost in scroll-back. Paul abandoned the entire arrangement because it was 'too complicated.' Tammy explicitly asked Split Lease to 'create the arrangements.' Both hosts and guests leave negotiations unsure of exact terms, with no referenced agreement. The formlessness of the negotiation erodes the trust the arrangement depends on.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No marketplace provides structured multi-dimensional housing negotiation. Even Airbnb is take-it-or-leave-it. A proposal system that pre-populates 80% of terms from listing data and presents the guest with a confirmation task (not a construction task) transforms the highest-stakes moment in the journey from anxiety-producing to confidence-building.
elements.description: A structured proposal card that the guest sees after clicking 'Create Proposal' on a listing. The card pre-populates terms from the listing: selected nights (from the search), nightly rate, move-in date, duration, deposit amount, and house rules. The guest reviews and confirms each section, with the ability to adjust specific terms. A cost summary updates live. The CTA is 'Send Proposal to Sarah' -- warm, personal, and specific. The host receives the proposal as a clean, evaluable package they can Accept, Counter, or Decline. Counter-offers highlight what changed. The accepted proposal becomes a permanent reference document.

elements.name: Active Stay Dashboard with Weekly Glance
elements.problem_it_solves: Every marketplace disappears after booking. The active stay -- the longest and most consequential phase -- receives zero product investment anywhere. Cristina pleads 'if you can do the work for me.' Tammy built an entire off-platform management empire with onsite managers and electronic locks. Guests and hosts manage payment tracking, cleaning, scheduling, and issues through scattered text messages and personal Venmo.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Nobody expects a platform to be present during the stay. This is the beer sommelier -- excellence in a space where nobody tries. A stay dashboard showing payment status, upcoming dates, house rules, and date-change tools would genuinely shock users who expect 'you're on your own now' after booking.
elements.description: A dashboard view that becomes the guest's home screen during an active lease. The top section is a 'Current Week Hero Card' showing this week's stay dates, check-in/check-out times, and a cleaning status indicator. Below: a payment timeline (paid/upcoming/overdue visualized as a horizontal track with purple dots), a quick-actions row (Change Dates, Message Host, View House Rules, Report Issue), and a 'Next 4 Weeks' calendar strip showing upcoming stay nights highlighted in purple. The dashboard is designed for the weekly glance: one screen, five seconds, full situational awareness.

elements.name: Returning Guest Relationship Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Every platform treats each booking as independent, discarding accumulated trust. Tag has a seasonal tenant who 'loves the place but doesn't wanna be here winter' -- no platform captures or facilitates that recurring relationship. After a successful 3-month stay, the guest starts from zero: same 'Is this still available?' flow, same trust vacuum. Good behavior goes unrewarded. The relationship is treated as if it never happened.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in any category models the host-guest relationship as a first-class data object. A card that shows shared history, accumulated trust, established norms, and a one-tap 'Propose New Stay' button transforms the platform from a marketplace for finding strangers into a relationship manager for maintaining partnerships.
elements.description: A card that appears on both the host's dashboard (in a 'Your Guests' section) and the guest's search page (in a 'Your Hosts' section). It shows: the other party's avatar and name, the number of completed stays, a relationship trust indicator (progresses through tiers: First Stay, Returning Guest, Trusted Pair), key stats from their shared history (total nights, avg review, on-time payment rate), and a prominent 'Propose New Stay' button that pre-populates terms from the last successful arrangement. A 'Returning Guest Discount' toggle lets hosts offer preferential rates to proven guests.

elements.name: Housing-Specific Review Dimensions
elements.problem_it_solves: Existing review systems (Airbnb's 5-star, Marketplace's thumbs-up) were designed for hospitality or goods, not cohabitation. A 4.8 from 200 Airbnb reviews tells you nothing about whether this host keeps the kitchen clean between ghost-roommate handoffs or respects quiet hours. William Romano's first concern: 'how clean it's going to be.' Frederick worried about sharing with someone he 'can't even really get to know.' Housing-specific review dimensions do not exist anywhere.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Purpose-built review dimensions for shared housing (cleanliness consistency, noise respect, communication, accuracy, rule adherence) represent a categorical leap from borrowed hospitality metrics. The reviews feed the Trust Stack and the Relationship Ledger, creating a compounding trust architecture that no competitor can replicate without years of accumulated data.
elements.description: A review submission and display system with 5 housing-specific dimensions instead of a single aggregate star rating. After each stay, both host and guest rate the other on: Cleanliness (between handoffs), Communication (responsiveness during stay), Accuracy (listing matched reality), Quiet Hours (noise respect), and Rule Adherence (followed agreed house rules). Each dimension gets a 1-5 score with an optional comment. The display shows a radar/pentagon chart for visual pattern recognition plus individual dimension bars. A text review accompanies the dimensional scores.

interaction_spec.aggregation: Profile-level scores aggregate across all stays. Individual stay reviews are also accessible.
